ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the minority experience in America.
I learned a lot about deviants in a society and what they have had to overcome to gain respect
I learned so much from this class. Every class the Professor was quoting new material and suggested really enlightening movies.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The readings due for each week could be more clearly stated. Comfortable and open environment to talk about some usually touchy topics.
The small class size allowed a lot of student involvement

The strengths are the main idea of the class - norms and deviance- is always present in every class. The readings are always connected. 

Weakness that some material I read I wish we went over in detail in class but when you go to Professor Anderson's office hours then he will discuss it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes. Prof Anderson is just looking for you to engage in the material in a meaningful way. If you do so for a least a couple of the readings then the midterm and final seem more like natural reflections than 10 page papers and it is not stressful.
Yes definitely- I learned a lot about not just society but myself
Yes because it focuses on material that is important when you want to understand the black man in society.
